Shows emotional response and interest when talking about baby's snowsuit and Hillary's desire to have children.
Defensively insists she understands and cares about children despite Hillary's skepticism.
Confronts Hillary with calm, measured words about jealousy and personal freedom, showing self-awareness and emotional control.
Turns and walks out quietly rather than escalating the confrontation, exhibiting control and restraint.
Refuses to take the dog with a sarcastic remark ('Do I want small pox?'), showing dismissiveness rather than kindness.
Struggles to navigate the courtyard, looking around as if searching for someone, indicating vulnerability and a possible longing for connection.
Freezes and seems about to run away when Leona embraces her, but allows the hug.
Tells Leona the truth about leaving her husband and looks away, fighting back tears, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Follows Leona after she laughs softly instead of expressing hurt or anger at Leona's ambiguous reaction.
Runs hesitantly into theater, seeks out John, expresses desperation and love, cries openly when rejected
Laughs nervously when confronted by John's packing, tries to lighten situation
Does not respond with anger or blame when John reveals their relationship is ending
Responds with small voice and tears to John's rejection, showing vulnerability and emotional openness.
Suddenly angry question to John about his disinterest in her path, showing frustration but sincere engagement.
Accepts John's rejection quietly and with sadness, without bitterness or hostility.
Refuses to beg a man who wronged her sister and stole her property, asserting her self-respect.
Punches the director after he slaps her, standing up for herself in the face of humiliation and abuse.
Shows anger and frustration openly on set, shouting at the director and criticizing the script and direction.
Breaks into a delighted smile upon hearing Hillary's sad news, asks if she'll name the baby after her.
Sits on the floor with Hillary putting baby clothes into a bureau, humming and sharing companionable silence.
Slowly turns with a smile of delight and wonder when Hillary puts her hand on her stomach during the hymn.
Takes Hillary's arm, preparing to accompany her despite perceived discomfort with sick people
Simpering smile at Richard, showing enthusiasm to see the 'little darling' on screen despite Hillary's disgust
Engages warmly with Richard about her background, openly sharing that she grew up in the Bronx
Looks away and shows troubled expression when discussing her ambivalence about show business, revealing emotional sincerity
Expresses a heartfelt desire for a normal, family life and willingness to give up career for the right partner
Says 'I can't believe how perfect this is' upon entering Hillary's living room, indicating appreciation and positive regard
Cuts in aghast to correct misunderstandings, confidently engages in social interaction.
Shows vulnerability and indecisiveness about her career path and future.
Navigates romantic conversation with emotional openness and some ambivalence.
Dresses flamboyantly and excitedly seeks approval from Hillary.
Smiles sweetly and agrees to sing a song requested by Richard's mother to please her despite her discomfort.
Responds stiffly and hard over the phone to Esther, refusing to impersonate her and setting clear boundaries.
Attendant gently shakes her shoulder to wake her; CC responds with excitement and relief about upcoming flight.
Stares out the plane window lost in amusing thoughts, appearing calm and reflective.
Stands slightly away from Hillary in labor, clutching a surgical gown with a look of terror; admits fear of blood and medical instruments, unable to assist.
Offers comfort to Victoria by holding out her hand and acknowledging shared fear and meanness.
Reassures Victoria about her mother's condition with a gentle smile and optimistic explanation.
Fights back tears after leaving the hospital, showing emotional vulnerability.
Encourages Victoria to disregard others' judgment and enjoy clamming despite potential embarrassment.
Invites Hillary to join her and others at the dock despite Hillary's reluctance.
Insists Hillary get dressed and stop isolating herself, despite Hillary's anger.
Apologizes to Hillary for losing her temper and acknowledges difficulty of situation.
Tells Hillary to stop living as if she is dead and to keep fighting
Slams out of the room after confrontation, showing emotional intensity but no visible empathy in that moment
Expresses on TV interview that she feels things deeply and is a deeply emotional person
Confidently asserts her knowledge about her friend, demonstrating strong memory and control in social interaction.
Playfully challenges Hillary but maintains composure and control, showing social skill and confidence.
Dismisses Hillary's accusation of making things up without losing confidence, indicating intelligent self-assurance.
Pays the taxi driver generously without hesitation despite exhaustion.
Quietly buys yellow roses before visiting Hillary in the hospital.
Hesitates before entering the cardiac care unit but proceeds to see Hillary.
Touches Victoria's wet coat gently and warns her she might get a cold.
Shares discovery of old letters from Victoria's mother and shows emotional vulnerability.
Reassures Victoria that she doesn't have to live with her if she doesn't want to, emphasizing others also want her.
Offers to call Victoria's father despite tense circumstances.
Admits to feeling inadequate and selfish as a potential mother figure.
Firmly tells Victoria she cannot live in her house, which causes pain and silence.
